nodes.content: George is suffering from ankylosing spondylitis, which causes various problems in his everyday life and many difficulties in fulfilling his obligations and work schedule. He is 52 years old, he lives alone but has many friends. He has been diagnosed at the age of 27 and since has been on therapy to manage the pain and the inflammation in his joints, but during the last month he has been suffering from intense pain at his shoulder and lower back. As a result he has been having increasing difficulty in his everyday work and activities. His doctor advised him to begin physiotherapy sessions and later some mild exercise, as well as trying to minimize his daily bodily stress. George decided to follow his doctor's advice.
nodes.title: George is suffering from ankylosing spondylitis.

buttons.label: Ignore the pain as much as he could and carry on with his gardening.
Take a rest and ask someone else to handle the gardening.
Take a rest for the time being and continue with the gardening the next day.

nodes.content: A week after his first physiotherapy session, George had to do some gardening at home. In the afternoon the pain at his back and shoulder got very intense and he was wondering what he should do:
nodes.title: Home chores

buttons.label: Talk about the problem with his doctor.
Ask his work supervisor if he could cut down on his working hours.
Ignore the pain and continue working at the same rate since he had recently been promoted and he didn't want to let his supervisor down.

nodes.content: Over the next months, George was promoted in the company he was working for. His work load was increased and he had to work overtime on a regular basis. Often he was experiencing intense body pain after coming home from work. He decided to:
nodes.title: Problems at work

buttons.label: Seek out a second opinion from a couple of different reumatologists in order to try out some new medication.
Talk to his attending reumatologist about his problem with the current medication.
Ignore his pain and continue taking his medication as before.

nodes.content: George over the next months was beginning to feel that his medication was not as effective as it had been. His pain was getting worse and he was feeling his body quite rigid. He thought and decided to:
nodes.title: Relationship with his attending doctor

buttons.label: Talk to his friends about helping him with packing his things and moving them into his new apartment.
Pack his things alone and move them at his own pace into the new apartment.
Talk to his friends about his current needs so they could offer advice or possibly help him out.

nodes.content: George was feeling a lot better and the pain had subsided significantly. However he had to move out of his old apartment and realized that it was likely he would need some help. He decided to:
nodes.title: Significant others

buttons.label: Talk about the pain with his attending doctor.

Seek out the counsel of a mental health professional.

nodes.content: George realized that his friends and relatives were very supportive but felt that they couldn't really realize the amount of pain he was in. Occasionally he thought that none could. He decided that he should do something about it:
nodes.title: Pain management

buttons.label: Contact his family doctor.
Take some painkillers and anti-inflammatory drugs till he starts feeling better.

nodes.content: The next day his back pain was much worse. It seemed almost impossible to get out of bed. He had to take a day off work. He thought that he shouldn't have stressed his body that much and decided to:

Unfortunately, inactiveness can lead to loss of joint movement, contraction, and loss of muscle strength. nodes.content: The doctor told him that he shouldn't be tiring out himself that much and should find a way to lower his stress since it was having an effect on his pain level. George decided to follow his doctor's advice. He realized that during the last weeks he had stressed himself too much  due to his desire to perform well at his work. It was likely that the increase in pain level could be related to that. For more advice, click on Supporting Information.

nodes.support: Sometimes it is difficult to ask for help. The less independent you feel, the harder it is to admit that sometimes you need someone to help you in a difficult time. It is not easy to admit to ourselves that we can not do things as easily as we could before. Communication with your closest people is especially important in difficult times, especially with people who are well aware of your health condition, and preferably people who live with you (partner, children, other family members). For your personalized support, you can get in touch with psychologists specialized in chronic pain, anonymously and free of charge, by calling the Psychological Support Line of the Hellenic League Against Rheumatism (EL.E.AN.A): 210 8237302, available Monday to Friday 10:00-16:00 or via email at helpline@arthritis.org.gr

nodes.support: Depending on how severe your condition and disability are, there may be obvious symptoms of your rheumatic disease that will make it unlikely to remain hidden from others. In this case, you should inform your potential employer about your situation in the context of what you are able to do in your job. This gives you the opportunity to discuss how you can manage your work and your situation, for example by working on flexible hours or by possibly adjusting the workplace where you are.
nodes.content: After a short time, the workload was significantly less and he had more time to adjust to the demands of his new position. At the same time his pain level was decreased.
